node.title: There are three theories for where Omicron came from, and they're all still on the table
node.alt: Illustration of planet Earth wearing a face mask.
node.description: While the emergence of new COVID variants isÂ expected, the new, highly mutated Omicron variant has taken many experts by surprise.
node.content:
["The idea of a mutating virus might sound a bit scary \u2014\u00a0more akin to something out of science fiction than a real health emergency.", "But in reality, all viruses mutate, and coronaviruses do so at a relatively high rate.", "So far, thousands of small changes have been seen in the evolution of SARS-CoV-2, the virus which causes COVID-19.", "And while the emergence of new COVID variants is to be expected, the new, highly mutated Omicron variant has taken many experts by surprise.", "So what is it that makes Omicron distinct? Where did it potentially come from? And why are we seeing it now?", "
How and why viruses mutate
", "Viruses aren't technically living things \u2014\u00a0they rely on the cells of other organisms to survive and reproduce.", "In order for SARS-CoV-2 to replicate, it hijacks the machinery of our cells and makes thousands of copies of itself using its own genetic material.", "Occasionally, during this replication process, tiny mistakes are made, causing small mutations to be introduced to the virus's genome.", "", "
The genetic code of SARS-CoV-2 is a string of RNA of about 30,000 bases, or letters.(Pixabay:\u00a0BlenderTimer)
", "Most of the time, these mistakes are inconsequential, says Jennifer Juno, a senior research fellow at The Doherty Institute.", "\"But occasionally, those mutations will have an impact,\" Dr Juno said.", "\"They might make the virus a little bit more likely to be transmitted, a bit easier to replicate, or maybe they will help the virus to evade our immune response.", "\"Those mutations can be transmitted onward and onward, and eventually they'll spread enough that we'll detect that, and that may become a variant of concern.\"", "The evolution of new variants is driven by the process of natural selection.", "The Delta variant, for example, eventually grew to outcompete other COVID variants because it spreads faster and, research suggests, more effectively.", "
What makes Omicron different?
", "Omicron is the latest COVID variant of concern to be identified by the World Health Organization (WHO).", "\"It's interesting because it carries more mutations than the other variants of concern we've seen so far,\" Dr Juno said.", "When scientists first looked at Omicron's genetic sequence, they found more than 50 mutations, 32 of which are on the all-important spike protein.", "Of particular concern is the fact that several of Omicron's mutations have been seen in other variants and are associated with increased transmissibility and the ability to evade immune protection.", "", "
What do we know about the Omicron variant?
", "\"It's the same basic virus, the same genetic structure, and it's got mostly the same sequence,\" Eddie Holmes, a leading viral evolution expert at the University of Sydney, told the Health Report.", "\"But the spike protein \u2014\u00a0the protein that sits on the surface of the virus that interacts with host cells, the one that we use our vaccines to work against \u2026 that's very, very different.", "Of the more than 30 mutations found on the spike protein, 10 are located in the \"receptor-binding domain\" \u2014\u00a0the part that interacts with the body's ACE-2 receptors and mediates the virus's entry into our cells.", "\"[Omicron] is certainly novel in that respect,\" Professor Holmes said.", "\"The really key question is how well the vaccines will prevent infection [with Omicron] \u2026 and more importantly, disease.\"", "While Omicron's changes warrant concern, it's still too early to say how the variant's unusual combination of mutations will behave in large populations.", "It's worth remembering that there have been other COVID variants with concerning mutations that have ultimately faded out of the spotlight.", "The Beta variant, for example, evolved a strong ability to evade our immune defences, but it proved to be poor at transmitting, and was eventually overrun by Delta.", "\"It's actually quite hard to predict how each mutation is going to work because it's interacting with a lot of things,\" Professor Holmes said.", "
Clues about where Omicron came from
", "Exactly what led to the emergence of Omicron is still unclear.", "\"At the moment, it's a little bit hard to know,\" Professor Holmes said.", "\"The evolutionary lineage \u2014\u00a0so where it is derived from \u2014\u00a0appears to have existed probably in 2020, so it has not come from Delta, it's actually a separate branch of its evolution.\"", "Omicron was first reported to the WHO by South African scientists on November 24, but it may have been circulating long before that.", "", "
In 2021, Professor Holmes won the Prime Minister's Prize for Science for his work on COVID-19 and viral evolution.(Eddie Holmes (Louise Cooper/Uni Syd))
", "\"One [theory] is that it may have been hidden somewhere, perhaps in southern Africa, and we haven't detected it for many months \u2014\u00a0it has kind of gone on silently and then suddenly appeared,\" Professor Holmes said.", "Earlier this week, health authorities in Europe reported that the variant was present in the Netherlands as early as November 19.", "Dr Juno says Omicron's high number of mutations indicate it may have come from a single immunocompromised patient who struggled to beat the virus.", "\"We know there are cases where people are chronically infected with SARS-CoV-2, so their immune system isn't able to win against the virus very quickly,\" she said.", "\"Their infection carries on for a long period of time, and when that happens, the virus \u2014\u00a0as it replicates within that person \u2014\u00a0can accumulate more mutations.\"", "Instead of the virus being cleared away quickly and effectively, it lingers, evading antibodies and adapting around the body's immune defences.", "When the virus eventually infects its next host, it's clocked up a collection of new and potentially dangerous\u00a0mutations.", "A third theory is that Omicron may have emerged through an animal host, Professor Holmes said.", "\"Maybe the virus got into an animal somewhere \u2026 it evolved in an animal \u2014\u00a0and that explains some of these strange changes \u2014\u00a0and then it re-emerged in humans,\" he said.", "\"All those three routes are still on the table for discussion.\"", "
Vaccine inequity leaves the world vulnerable
", "There's no particular reason why the Omicron variant has appeared now. Viral evolution, while expected, isn't always predictable.", "The emergence of a new variant, however, underscores the importance of high vaccination coverage and equitable access to vaccines, Dr Juno says.", "", "
The Omicron variant has prompted international travel bans and the reintroduction of certain quarantine measures.(Getty Images:\u00a0Win McNamee)
", "While about 55 per cent of the global population has received at least one dose of a COVID-19 vaccine, in low-income countries, that rate is closer to just 6 per cent.", "\"If you take away those opportunities for the virus to be transmitted and to spread across large numbers of people, you're really reducing the chances for those mutations to occur.\"", "
Are we stuck in a cycle of variants?
", "Dr Juno says\u00a0it's\u00a0very likely the world will continue to see new COVID-19 variants emerging in the short- to medium-term, particularly while large swathes of the global population remain unvaccinated.", "\"Eventually, we are going to achieve some degree of population-level immunity, whether that's through infection, vaccination or a combination of both, so I don't think we'll be stuck in these cycles endlessly,\" she said.", "\"But at the same time, I think we now need to acknowledge the possibility for variants to develop and change.\"", "According to Professor Holmes, the evolutionary pressure on the virus \u2014\u00a0and subsequent likelihood of new variants emerging \u2014\u00a0is likely to be strongest in the next three to four\u00a0years.", "\"That's when I expect the evolution to be most rapid, because it's where you've got populations that are still unvaccinated and some are partially vaccinated,\" he said.", "\"It's kind of a complex set of environments that is going to push the virus.\"", "How long that will go on for is harder to say, and will largely depend on how urgently global vaccine inequities are addressed."]
